pred_note:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 Mrs. Anderson, a 44-year-old female, presented with a complaint of a left shoulder pain for a week. She had taken Tylenol, which did not help. The pain started in her gymnastics class while performing a certain move.  
PHYSICAL EXAM
 The doctor examined the patient and asked her to move her shoulder. Any kind of movement on her left shoulder caused pain. The doctor requested a look at her x-ray which showed that there was no fracture. He observed that the injury was in the joint.  
RESULTS
 No fracture was detected on the patient's x-ray.  
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
 The doctor prescribed the patient with ibuprofen of 600 milligrams to be taken thrice daily for one week. He suggested that if there was still pain after a week, the patient could use an ice or heat pad to relieve the pain. The doctor advised that the patient should rest and not use her left arm for heavy lifting. He also told her that in case the pain persisted after three weeks, she could come back for further evaluation. Finally, the doctor advised the patient to try Aleve, an alternative to Ibuprofen, for pain relief.

Mrs. Anderson, a 44-year-old female, presented with a complaint of a left shoulder pain for a week. She had taken Tylenol, which did not help. The pain started in her gymnastics class while performing a certain move.

The doctor examined the patient and asked her to move her shoulder. Any kind of movement on her left shoulder caused pain. The doctor requested a look at her x-ray which showed that there was no fracture. He observed that the injury was in the joint. No fracture was detected on the patient's x-ray.

The doctor prescribed the patient with ibuprofen of 600 milligrams to be taken thrice daily for one week. He suggested that if there was still pain after a week, the patient could use an ice or heat pad to relieve the pain. The doctor advised that the patient should rest and not use her left arm for heavy lifting. He also told her that in case the pain persisted after three weeks, she could come back for further evaluation. Finally, the doctor advised the patient to try Aleve, an alternative to Ibuprofen, for pain relief.
gt_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT:

Left shoulder pain.

HPI:

Ms. Anderson is a 44-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of the left shoulder. She states that she was in gymnastics 1 week ago. The pain has been present since that time. She has pain with any type of movement of her left shoulder. She had taken Tylenol for 2 to 3 days with no improvement in her symptoms.

She has a surgical history significant for prior left upper extremity surgery.

EXAM

Examination of the left shoulder shows pain with range of motion.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder, 3 views obtained on today's visit show no obvious signs of fracture.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended taking ibuprofen 600 mg three times per day for one week. If the patient does not have relief from the ibuprofen she will take Aleve. The patient may also utilize ice or heat packs. She should rest her left arm and may not lift or carry heavy objects with her left arm. The patient should follow up in three to four weeks if the pain persists. We may repeat the left shoulder x-ray at that time.

:

Left shoulder pain. :

Ms. Anderson is a 44-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of the left shoulder. She states that she was in gymnastics 1 week ago. The pain has been present since that time. She has pain with any type of movement of her left shoulder. She had taken Tylenol for 2 to 3 days with no improvement in her symptoms.

She has a surgical history significant for prior left upper extremity surgery.
Examination of the left shoulder shows pain with range of motion. X-rays of the left shoulder, 3 views obtained on today's visit show no obvious signs of fracture.

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended taking ibuprofen 600 mg three times per day for one week. If the patient does not have relief from the ibuprofen she will take Aleve. The patient may also utilize ice or heat packs. She should rest her left arm and may not lift or carry heavy objects with her left arm. The patient should follow up in three to four weeks if the pain persists. We may repeat the left shoulder x-ray at that time.
